expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 2.50 cycles. At this rate:
 - 25% of peak load performance is reached (16.00 out of 64.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
 - 20% of peak store performance is reached (6.40 out of 32.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

header: 0% of peak computational performance is used (0.00 out of 48.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
- Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
 - Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
gain.title: Code clean check
gain.txt:
Detected a slowdown caused by scalar integer instructions (typically used for address computation).
By removing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.50 to 2.00 cycles (1.25x speedup).

gain.workaround:
- Try another compiler or update/tune your current one
 - Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
  * If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly
  * If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA)
gain.details:
All SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is not vectorized.
4 data elements could be processed at once in vector registers.
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.50 to 0.62 cycles (4.00x speedup).

gain.workaround:
- Read less array elements
 - Write less array elements
 - Provide more information to your compiler:
  * hardcode the bounds of the corresponding 'for' loop
gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt:
Performance is limited by:
 - reading data from caches/RAM (load units are a bottleneck)
 - writing data to caches/RAM (the store unit is a bottleneck)

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.50 to 1.00 cycles (2.50x speedup).
